title: The Potato Eaters
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Depicts peasant hardship and early realism in Van Gogh's work.
story: Van Gogh wanted to depict peasants as they really were. He deliberately chose coarse, ugly models, thinking that they would be more natural and unspoiled than the bourgeoisie. He wrote to his brother Theo: 'I have tried to emphasize that those people, eating their potatoes in the lamplight, have dug the earth with those very hands they put in the dish, and so it speaks of manual labor and how they have honestly earned their food.'

title: The Starry Night
credits: The Museum of Modern Art, New York
museum: Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), New York
description: Turbulent, emotional sky painted while Van Gogh was at Saint-Rémy asylum.
story: Painted in June 1889, it depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, just before sunrise, with the addition of an imaginary village. It is regarded as among the finest works of Western art.

title: Sunflowers
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Vivid still life symbolizing gratitude and friendship.
story: Van Gogh's paintings of Sunflowers are among his most famous. He did them in Arles, in the south of France, in 1888 and 1889. Vincent wrote to Theo: 'The sunflower is mine, in a way.'

title: The Bedroom
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Personal depiction of his room in Arles.
story: Van Gogh prepared his room himself with simple furniture and his own art on the walls. The bright colours were meant to express absolute 'repose' or 'sleep'.

title: Portrait of Dr. Gachet
credits: Musée d'Orsay, Paris
description: Psychological portrait of Dr. Gachet.
story: Dr. Gachet was a homeopathic doctor and artist with whom Van Gogh resided following a spell in an asylum at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence. Gachet took care of Van Gogh during the final months of his life.

title: Wheatfield with Crows
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: One of Van Gogh's final paintings, expressing emotional turmoil.
story: This is one of Van Gogh's most famous paintings. It is often claimed that this was his very last work. The menacing sky, the crows and the dead-end path are said to refer to the end of his life approaching. But that is just a persistent myth.

title: Irises
credits: J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles
museum: J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles
description: Vibrant work showing purple irises against orange marigolds.
story: Van Gogh painted this within a week of entering the asylum at Saint-Rémy. He called it 'the lightning conductor for my illness' because he felt that he could keep himself from going insane by continuing to paint.

title: Self-Portrait with Bandaged Ear
credits: Courtauld Gallery, London
description: Painted after Van Gogh's self-mutilation incident.
story: In this self-portrait, Van Gogh is wearing a blue fur cap and a green overcoat, with a bandage covering his ear. It documents his return to painting after the incident with Gauguin.

title: The Yellow House
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Depicts the house in Arles where Van Gogh lived and worked.
story: Van Gogh rented four rooms in the right wing of the 'Yellow House' on Place Lamartine in Arles. He wanted to turn it into a 'Studio of the South' where artists could live and work together.

title: Café Terrace at Night
credits: Kröller-Müller Museum, Otterlo
description: First painting where Van Gogh used starry backgrounds.
story: Van Gogh was fascinated by the night and the effects of artificial light. Here he depicts the terrace of a café on the Place du Forum in Arles, lit by a large gas lantern.

title: Almond Blossom
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Painted to celebrate the birth of his nephew.
story: Large blossom branches against a blue sky were one of Van Gogh's favourite subjects. Almond trees flower early in the spring making them a symbol of new life.

title: The Church at Auvers
credits: Musée d'Orsay, Paris
description: One of Van Gogh's final works.
story: The church sits on a hill overlooking the village of Auvers. Van Gogh painted it in cool, violet tones, contrasting with the bright green of the grass.

title: The Red Vineyard
credits: Pushkin Museum, Moscow
description: The only painting Van Gogh sold during his lifetime.
story: Van Gogh painted this vineyard in November, when the leaves had turned red and orange. It captures the intense colours of autumn in Provence.

title: The Sower
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Inspired by Millet, featuring a sower against a sunset.
story: Van Gogh had a special interest in sowers. To him, the sower represented the eternal cycle of life and death, of sowing and harvesting.

title: The Siesta
credits: Musée d'Orsay, Paris
description: Peasants resting in the shade.
story: Van Gogh copied this composition from a drawing by Millet, translating it into his own colourful style.

title: Starry Night Over the Rhône
credits: Musée d'Orsay, Paris
description: Starry night scene over the Rhône River.
story: Van Gogh painted this spot on the banks of the Rhône, just a minute or two's walk from the Yellow House. The gaslights of Arles reflect in the water.

title: Blossoming Almond Branch
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: A study of a flowering almond branch.
story: Van Gogh painted this small study of a flowering almond branch in a glass shortly after arriving in Arles. He was struck by the early spring blossom.

title: A Wheatfield with Cypresses
credits: National Gallery, London
description: Swirling clouds and swaying wheat field.
story: Van Gogh regarded this sunny landscape as one of his best summer paintings. He made three versions of it.

title: Tree Roots
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: Considered by some to be his very last painting.
story: The painting is an almost abstract jumble of tree trunks and roots. It was painted on the morning of 27 July 1890, the day Van Gogh shot himself.

title: Skull of a Skeleton with Burning Cigarette
credits: Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam (Vincent van Gogh Foundation)
description: A humorous and macabre work.
story: This skeleton with a burning cigarette is a juvenile joke. Van Gogh painted it while studying at the art academy in Antwerp.

title: Peasant Woman Digging
description: A study of peasant life.

title: Sorrow
description: A poignant drawing of Sien Hoornik.
